I consider myself pro-life and thank Mr. Kristof for accurately terming it a medical abortion. But being pro-life includes being pro- the life of the mother, and abortions in developing countries, especially illegal abortions, come with a horrific maternal (and, therefore, fetal) death rate.

It appears that this *particular* area of law is one in which the well-known tendency of people to follow a law, merely because it is the law, does not hold. Criminalizing abortions, according to the studies I have seen, does not reduce the abortion rate; reducing unwanted pregnancies, and the mother being a member of a culture that values the unborn and assists mothers in need of support, are far better at preventing deaths both maternal and filial.

The advent of medical abortion in developing countries is a good thing, even to a pro-lifer; its disappearance when we empower women in these nations to avoid unwanted pregnancies in the first place, and have the support in place for an extra mouth to feed when necessary, will be much, much better.

First and foremost, I detest the political terms "pro-choice" and" pro-life". I, and I venture to assume many others, are neither according to the accepted definitions. I find abortion abhorrent. I also recognize that it has existed from the beginning of time and will always exist. Extremists who think that holding signs and screaming outside of facilities that provide abortions are on a fool's errand. How many of the saved babies will they commit to care for? Furthermore, most of those extremists have no interest or compassion for women who find themselves in the position to have to consider aborting a baby. While a very few women do so casually, for most it is a wrenching decision. I have never forgotten the woman who was deserted by her husband and left to care for two children on her own with very limited resources. She was ecstatic when he returned and wanted to reconcile. During the brief time of reconciliation she became pregnant. He then deserted her again. She could find no way that she could have another baby with along the attendant challenges of caring for a newborn, still care for her two children financially and emotionally and possibly losing her job. Sadly, she chose abortion. She saw no other option.

Would it have been better if this woman, and so many others, had to resort to dangerous, untrained abortionists? Would it have been better if she had died during an illegal abortion and left her two children alone? These are the questions that so called "pro-life" people have to answer. These are the undesirable choices we have to make. Obviously, the best approach is to prevent those pregnancies to begin with. Yet some "pro-life" individuals are also against contraception. That includes the Catholic Church (of which I was a member from birth) and makes no sense.

Can we possibly come together with the understanding that unplanned, unwanted pregnancy can be a horrible burden on women and living children? Can we do everything in our power to prevent women, where ever they live, from being in that position where abortion becomes a choice they have to make? Can we end the political fight and come together to a position where we reverence life from its beginning but understand that, in the real world, women will choose to end pregnancies even at the risk of their own lives? Will anyone listen?
Guild Hall's Museum and Theater

Jon Joensen - I understand your argument, but comparison to another evil (the mass production and slaughter of livestock in factory farms) does not excuse the actions of the Faroese, and others who defend the killing of whales and dolphins in the name of tradition. It is a false counter-argument.

The slaughter of whales not only looks barbaric - it is barbaric. Although it is not the most pressing of issues in the context of global climate change, environmental degradation and the mass extinction of species which we are currently witness to, the slaughter of cetaceans in the 21st century is one of the testing moral arguments of our time.

Little more than a 60-years ago, a single whaling company in Western Australia was taking about a 1000 sperm and humpback whales each year. Today Australia is one of the most vocal and active anti-whaling nations on the planet. Why is this so? Because, Australians woke up to the reality that cetaceans are complex, social, highly intelligent beings, and that killing them was simply wrong.

Research continues to show that cetaceans are capable of a level of self-awareness and learned cultural behaviour that puts them on a par with ourselves, to an extent where killing them should be abhorrent to all but the most callous and greed-driven individual.

Today the Faroese enjoy a standard of living higher than most other developed nations, including the USA, so arguing that the practice is necessary for food is disingenuous. Yes, you are honest about the fact that you and your neighbours like to kill whales in the name of tradition. But are you really being honest to your soul?

Respectfully,
Simon Avery

I think you misunderstand the term "long standing cultural traditions". It´s not like the Faroes just invented whale-killing for the fun of it. It is/was/always has been an essentiel part along with fishing to providing food on the table.

And they do remain local!! It´s strictly prohibited by law to export whale-meat from the Faroes, but not that I would expect anything else but ignorance on your behalf on that matter. They are also ONLY feeding the local people by old traditions that anybody from the community showing up when the whales are being divided can stake a claim regardless if they actually participated or not. In later years some meat has been available for sale (still prohibited for export) to secure faroese of other areas of the country to be able to buy it. It varies a lot where around these islands the whales will be found.

And there is no such thing as “local waters” anymore. We’re a global world now. The C02 in China eventually reaches us just like the C02 we produce ultimately reaches them.

And unfortunately both the CO2 that you and China produce eventually reaches the Faroe Islands (eventually is of course an understatement since it already has reached us ages ago!!). Sadly the reversed thing can´t be said since our contribution is so minor that it blows away like a fart in the wind.

We all know the waters in which these mammals swim ultimately evaporates, goes up into the atmosphere to create clouds, and those clouds make rain that falls everywhere. So this isn’t about “their rights” to do whatever they want in their “local waters” anymore. Their waters are a part of our global commons. What they do effects the entire global ecosystem.

wmar --- In this universe the physics of CO2 is well understood. Most of the variance seen in the past 13 decades is due to CO2. There are small contibutions from aersols and so on as well as internal variability. Usin the AMO as a index for those minor wobbles around the CO2 driven trend, almost everything is explained:
http://www.realclimate.org...

While climate is not at all akin to a mass-spring system, there being no restoring force, it is possible that there is, in addition to CO2+AMO, a linear trend. This was explored in Tol, R.S.J. and A.F. de Vos (1998), ‘A Bayesian Statistical Analysis of the Enhanced Greenhouse Effect’, Climatic Change, 38, 87-112. I did the same with the simple model used in the study linked above. The result trend over the 13 decades was found to be 0.063 K/century, hardly enough to matter.

That's how it works in this universe
